importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Combs was arrested in September 2024, marking the beginning of a high-profile legal case that garnered international attention.
The article was published on October 21, 2025, indicating the latest developments in Combs' appeal process following his conviction and sentencing.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from September 2024 to October 2025 covers the timeline of Combs’ arrest, trial, sentencing, and the announcement of his legal appeal, illustrating the prolonged legal and public scrutiny.

keyTakeAways: Sean 'Diddy' Combs has been convicted of two counts of transportation to engage in prostitution and acquitted on charges of sex trafficking and racketeering.
Combs’ legal team has formally notified a US federal court of their intention to appeal both the conviction and the 50-month prison sentence.
Judge Arun Subramanian imposed a 50-month sentence, a $500,000 fine, and five years of probation, citing the need to send a strong message about accountability for abuse of women.
Combs initially requested a 14-month sentence, but prosecutors sought over 11 years, reflecting the severity of the allegations.

The case centered on Combs’ alleged use of influence in the music industry to run a sex trafficking operation involving 'freak-offs' with female partners and male escorts, particularly in his relationship with Cassandra Ventura and a woman known as Jane.
Combs admitted during the sentencing that his actions were 'disgusting, shameful, and sick' and apologized to the women who testified against him.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Sean 'Diddy' Combs, a major figure in the music industry, has been convicted of two counts of transportation to engage in prostitution and acquitted on charges of sex trafficking and racketeering. His legal team has filed a notice of appeal, targeting both the conviction and the 50-month prison sentence imposed by Judge Arun Subramanian, who emphasized accountability for abuse of women. The case, which began with Combs’ arrest in September 2024 and involved testimony from women like Cassandra Ventura and Jane, centers on allegations that Combs used his influence to coerce female partners into participating in 'freak-offs' with male escorts. Despite Combs’ public apology and admission of wrongdoing, the jury found him guilty only on the less severe charges, sparking widespread media attention and raising broader questions about power, consent, and accountability in high-profile relationships.
title: Sean 'Diddy' Combs says he plans to appeal sentence and conviction
